newsitem.title: UK: U.S., British first ladies usher in new era.
newsitem.headline: U.S., British first ladies usher in new era.

text.p: U.S. First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton visited her British counterpart Cherie Blair on Thursday in a closely-watched meeting of two of the world's most powerful wives.
Wifely status aside, both women are brainy, successful lawyers and devoted mothers who symbolise the shift in power on either side of the Atlantic to the post-war generation.

"They have a certain position," said Hannah Davies, among the crowds jostling to see the first ladies out and about in London. "They did not become the wife of the president or prime minister for nothing. I think they must lead interesting lives."
Yet while Hillary is in her second term as U.S. first lady, Cherie has had less than a month to settle into her new role as spouse to the most powerful man in Britain.
Labour leader Tony Blair was swept to power on May 1 and is known to share many many political leanings and generational traits with President Bill Clinton.
Much has also been made of their wives' similarities.
Stylish, opinionated and political, the two women ended a long tradition in both countries of first wives demurely staying home while their husbands ran the world.
Both are young mothers who have pursued very well-paid legal careers. They are also said to be brighter and more left-leaning than their husbands.
Yet while Hillary has courted controversy for her outspoken political comments and key role in shaping U.S. policy, Cherie is largely an unknown.
She stuck close to her husband during the election campaign but has doggedly avoided speaking to the media and made clear she plans to continue her job -- not meddle in his.

Yet true to tradition, their two-piece suits were duly pored over -- blonde Hillary wore sky blue while brunette Cherie chose dove grey -- and the agenda was a tried-and-tested formula of lunch folllowed by a spot of theatre.
"They lunched privately, with some aides from Mrs Clinton's party and some staff from Downing Street," said a spokesman.
From Downing Street, the two women sped by stretch limo to the Globe theatre, an exquisite recreation of the riverside playhouse where Shakespeare's plays were staged 400 years ago.
The open-topped wooden playhouse officially opened this month after a painstaking renovation pioneered by the late U.S. actor-director Sam Wanamaker.

"We're delighted that the only day the first lady is in town she has come to us," said Globe spokeswoman Nina Jacob. "It was an American who hatched the idea and we owe them a lot for helping us re-discover something British. We already get lots of American visitors and I'm sure this will only encourage more."

The two women toured an exhibition before watching the first half of Henry V in baking sun. Most of the audience sat on wooden benches or stood while the VIPs peered down from the so-called gentlemen's rooms, precursor to the modern-day box.
One 51-year-old onlooker said the women, who chatted animatedly ahead of the performance, seemed to get along well.
"The body language seemed to be all right," she said. "I presume having a law background, they will have a lot in common. They're both quite bright cookies with their own careers."
The Clintons were due to head home later on Thursday after a one-day visit aimed at cementing the new "special relationship" between Blair's Britain and Clinton's United States.
